image.altText: A man in the suit on the left looks happy with himself and a man in the right in a suit looks up up at the gallery

items.synopsis: With public sector cuts ahead, GST revenue falling and major projects on the way that are vulnerable to cost blow-outs, Tasmania's budget position can be described as precarious at best, writes Adam Langenberg.

title.children: 'Stormy seas' ahead, Tasmanian treasurer warns, as budget delivers few clear winners

image.altText: A tourniquet is applied to a woman's arm in preparation for a blood test, for a story about chickenpox and pregnancy

items.synopsis: The inquiry has recommended significant changes to Australia's health system for reproductive and sexual health care.

title.children: Accessible abortion, contraception incentives and Telehealth extensions: What a new report means for health care

image.altText: Nurses and doctor pictured during medical procedure, generic image.

items.synopsis: The Tasmanian government promised a budget that focused on health, education and cost of living. See how these sectors fared — and who are the winners and losers of this year's budget.

title.children: Who are the winners and losers of Tasmania's budget?

image.altText: Marcus Stewart stands in a park, dressed in an Akubra and t-shirt bearing the message 'Always Was, Always Will Be'.

items.synopsis: The Uluru dialogue six years ago led to the Statement from the Heart and, ultimately, the upcoming referendum that could deliver constitutional change.

title.children: Voice campaigner calls for overhaul of national Indigenous agency on anniversary of Uluru statement

image.altText: A wall collapses during a building fire in the Central Business District of Sydney.

items.synopsis: Fire crews worked throughout the night to mop up a blaze that destroyed a seven-storey heritage building in Sydney's inner city.

title.children: Investigations continue into major inner-city Sydney blaze as residents wait to return home

image.altText: Two Australian army infantry fighting vehicles.

items.synopsis: Lucrative construction work on new high-tech Army infantry fighting vehicles (IFVs) could be sent overseas under an option being considered by the Albanese government to acquire the lethal land capability more urgently.

title.children: Army's new infantry fighting vehicles could be built overseas to meet urgent strategic needs

image.altText: The HMAS Launceston under power

items.synopsis: HMAS Launceston is being decommissioned on June 1, ending a run of navy vessels named after the Tasmanian city dating back to 1942.

title.children: After a long and storied history, the name HMAS Launceston is set to disappear from the navy — for now, at least

image.altText: A close-up of an incandescent light-bulb with the word "POWER STRUGGLE" superimposed on it.

items.synopsis: Headline price increases of 25 per cent barely tell the story of struggling households at risk of falling behind in the energy transition.

title.children: Why price hikes are masking an energy divide that threatens to leave poor Australians behind

image.altText: Figuring out how to save money on energy bill

items.synopsis: Electricity prices are set to soar come July 1. Here's how you can save some money, while staying warm.

title.children: Energy prices are set to rise up to 25 per cent. Here's how you can save on bills heading into winter

image.altText: A woman standing in the dark staring off into the distance.

items.synopsis: At just two years old, Monica Wallabindi's mother was stolen from her family. She says National Sorry Day isn't about making anyone feel personally guilty or responsible, but acknowledging Australia's past.

title.children: Today is National Sorry Day, but many Indigenous Australians say they're still asked: 'Why should I apologise?'

image.altText: A nuclear power plant on a rocky shore

items.synopsis: Operators of the Fukushima nuclear power plant are set to release treated wastewater into the ocean. But already Japanese authorities are facing a barrage of criticism from fishermen.

title.children: Inside Japan's plan to release one million tonnes of water from its stricken nuclear plant

image.altText: A tourist is silhouetted as he takes pictures of Mount Nuptse in the Everest region.

items.synopsis: Australian engineer Jason Kennison is the 10th climber to die on Mount Everest this spring in one of the deadliest climbing seasons in recent history.

title.children: Why have there been so many deaths on Mount Everest this climbing season?

image.altText: Multiple packets of colourful pharmaceutical medicines.

items.synopsis: The Pharmacy Guild of Australia says 400 drugs are on the "critical" shortage list and 20 per cent of those would be out of stock due to the government's new 60-day script policy. But the data tells a different story.

title.children: We fact checked the Pharmacy Guild's claims about medicine shortages. Here's what we found

image.altText: Black and white photo of Gerd Heidemann standing, holding two large books, before group of men seated near microphones.

items.synopsis: In 1983 German magazine Stern thought it had a major scoop. It turned out to be a major hoax, and revealed a disturbing willingness to fall for a revised history of Hitler.

title.children: A forger tried to rewrite Hitler's history. Why did mainstream media fall for the hoax?

image.altText: a man wearing dark glasses walking out of the forencic department

items.synopsis: As a coroner found Sydney fraudster Melissa Caddick is dead, she spoke about the "strong suspicion" of police that Anthony Koletti has withheld information from investigators.

title.children: The last person to see Melissa Caddick alive was a 'significant burden' to police investigation, coroner finds

image.altText: Specimens in a jar on a table.

items.synopsis: Scientists calculate there are thousands of unidentified species living on the ocean floor between Hawaii and Mexico where deep-sea mining for critical minerals needed to build batteries is set to begin next year.

title.children: Thousands of unidentified deep-sea species found in part of Pacific Ocean earmarked for mining

image.altText: A middle aged man is speaking into a microphone. He is dressed in black with a black eyepatch. He sticks one finger up.

items.synopsis: The founder of far-right militant group Oath Keepers, Stewart Rhodes, is sentenced to 18 years in prison for seditious conspiracy in a failed bid to keep Donald Trump in the White House.

title.children: Longest Capitol riot sentence yet: Oath Keepers founder gets sentenced to 18 years in prison

image.altText: Mr Albanese gestures with both hands raised while speaking from someone's backyard a clothesline barely visible behind him.

items.synopsis: The notions of "left" and "right" don't mean a lot in today's Labor, except as groupings to dole out preselections, frontbench representation and other spoils, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: Does Labor still know its left from its right?

image.altText: A composite image of Joe Biden and Kevin McCarthy, two older white men.

items.synopsis: The US government appears closer to cutting a deal to raise its multi-trillion-dollar debt ceiling as a default looms, and Wall Street finishes higher after a rush on tech stocks. Follow live.

title.children: US debt ceiling deal edges closer as deadline looms, Wall Street gains on tech stock rush, ASX to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Data out from Germany overnight shows the country's economy has slipped into a recession, after household spending dipped due to the pressures of high inflation. Gross domestic product in Germany fell by 0.3% in the first three months of the year, and followed a decline of 0.5% in the final three months of last year. An economy is defined as being in recession after two successive negative quarters of economic growth. Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner said the GDP data showed "surprisingly negative signals". The country's economy minister Robert Habeck said Germany's previous high dependency on Russia for energy supply led to the recession, and growth forecasts were much bleaker. Household consumption was down 1.2% quarter on quarter after price, seasonal and calendar adjustments. Government spending also decreased significantly, by 4.9%, on the quarter.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Germany enters recession as inflation deters household spending

children.content: Data out from Germany overnight shows the country's economy has
slipped into a recession
, after household spending dipped due to the pressures of high inflation.
Gross domestic product in
Germany fell by 0.3%
in the first three months of the year, and followed
a decline of 0.5%
in the final three months of last year.
An economy is defined as being in recession after
two successive negative quarters
of economic growth.
Germany's finance minister Christian Lindner said the GDP data showed "surprisingly negative signals".
The country's economy minister Robert Habeck said Germany's previous
high dependency on Russia for energy supply
led to the recession, and growth forecasts were much bleaker.
Household consumption was down 1.2% quarter on quarter after price, seasonal and calendar adjustments. Government spending also decreased significantly, by 4.9%, on the quarter.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: UBS's acquisition of Credit Suisse is all but finished, after the European Commission approved the merger unconditionally. The Commission had been looking at whether the transaction would "significantly reduce competition", but ultimately concluded it wouldn't have an effect. The Commission wrote: Based on its market investigation, the Commission found that the merger would not significantly reduce competition in the markets where their activities overlap within the EEA (European Economic Area). In particular, the Commission found that the combined entity will continue facing significant competitive pressure from a wide range of competitors in all of those markets, including several major global banks as well as specialist providers and strong local players. The Commission therefore concluded that the proposed merger would not raise competition concerns on any of the markets examined in the EEA and cleared the transaction unconditionally. UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs in March in a government-backed deal to ward off contagion fears and a global banking crisis after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank and First Republic in the US.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EU approves UBS takeover of Credit Suisse

children.content: UBS's acquisition of Credit Suisse is all but finished, after the European Commission approved the merger unconditionally.
The Commission had been looking at whether the transaction would "significantly reduce competition", but ultimately concluded it wouldn't have an effect.
The Commission wrote:
Based on its market investigation, the Commission found that the merger
would not significantly reduce competition
in the markets where their activities overlap within the EEA (European Economic Area).

In particular, the Commission found that the combined entity will continue facing significant competitive pressure from a wide range of competitors in all of those markets, including several major global banks as well as specialist providers and strong local players.
The Commission therefore concluded that the proposed merger
would not raise competition concerns
on any of the markets examined in the EEA and cleared the transaction unconditionally.
UBS agreed to buy Credit Suisse for 3 billion Swiss francs in March in a government-backed deal to
ward off contagion fears and a global banking crisis
after the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, Signature Bank and First Republic in the US.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Let's stay on the US debt ceiling talks for a moment — specifically, what US President Joe Biden said at a press conference earlier. He started by reaffirming that the US defaulting on debt is not an option, but said while progress has been made there are some sticking points in negotiations with Speaker Kevin McCarthy. Here's some of what he had to say: "I want to be clear that the negotiations we're having with Speaker McCarthy is about the outlines of what the budget will look like, not about default. It's about competing visions for America. "Under my administration, we've already cut the deficit by $1.7 trillion in our first two years. But Speaker McCarthy and I have a very different view of who should bear the burden of additional efforts to get our fiscal house in order. "I don't believe the whole burden should fall on the backs of middle class and working class Americans." Biden said the Republicans "disagree" and are instead pushing for steep cuts, which would affect teachers, police, border patrol agents, and increase the wait times for social security claims. "I won't agree to that. I put forward a proposal to cut spending by more than $1 trillion, that freezes spending for the next two years. That's on top of the nearly $3 trillion in deficit reduction I previously proposed through a combination of spending cuts and new revenue raisers. "I propose making the wealthy begin to pay their fair share, which will reduce the deficit. But it won't cut programs for hardworking Americans depending on those funds in order to continue big tax returns for the wealthiest Americans.''
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Biden 'won't agree' to steep cuts put forward by Republicans in debt ceiling deal

children.content: Let's stay on the US debt ceiling talks for a moment — specifically, what
US President Joe Biden
said at a press conference earlier.
He started by reaffirming that the US defaulting on debt is not an option, but said while progress has been made there are some sticking points in negotiations with Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
Here's some of what he had to say:
"I want to be clear that the negotiations we're having with Speaker McCarthy is about the outlines of what the budget will look like, not about default. It's about competing visions for America.
"Under my administration, we've already cut the deficit by $1.7 trillion in our first two years. But
Speaker McCarthy and I have a very different view of who should bear the burden
of additional efforts to get our fiscal house in order.
"I don't believe the whole burden should fall on the backs of middle class and working class Americans."
Biden said the Republicans "disagree" and are instead pushing for steep cuts, which would affect teachers, police, border patrol agents, and increase the wait times for social security claims.

"I won't agree to that. I put forward a proposal to cut spending by more than $1 trillion, that freezes spending for the next two years. That's on top of the nearly $3 trillion in deficit reduction I previously proposed through a combination of spending cuts and new revenue raisers.
"I propose
making the wealthy begin to pay their fair share
, which will reduce the deficit. But it won't cut programs for hardworking Americans depending on those funds in order to continue big tax returns for the wealthiest Americans.''

props.alt: Joe Biden wearing aviators stands behind a lecturn.

children.content: (Reuters: Evelyn Hockstein)

image.altText: Luton Town fan with an orange and white hat on his face

image.altText: A composite image of headshots of Arlene, Matt and Freya.

items.synopsis: ChatGPT is currently banned in many schools. But where it's not, students — and their teachers — say they are using it to prepare for a future in which artificial intelligence is likely to be a big part of work and life.

title.children: ChatGPT's class divide: Are public school bans on the AI tool giving private school kids an unfair edge?

image.altText: A black and white historical photo of a young man wearing a suit

items.synopsis: Blond and boyish, Adelaide's Jimmy Melrose was an aviation sensation in his day, and achieved celebrity status by smashing records and flying solo to the UK. After he met his fate among the clouds, 100,000 people turned out to salute him.

title.children: This pilot prodigy flew to London on his own at 21 — then tragedy struck

image.altText: Image of a young girl.

title.children: Search of Portuguese dam in Madeleine McCann case draws to a close with little chance of breakthrough

image.altText: Composite image of Jake Sim with his seven-member boy group, ENHYPEN.
